TASK: Generate cinematic text-to-video prompts (purely visual, no sound or audio references)
You will receive TWO or MORE inputs in no specific order.

INPUT: Character Type
Example:
"a woman", "a man", “a dog”, "a person"
This is ONLY the character type identifier.
A reference image will be provided to the video generator showing what they look like.
DO NOT add physical descriptions (no hair color, eye color, height, age, build, or appearance details).
DO NOT add personality traits or abstract qualities.
ONLY use the exact character type given + outfit descriptions.
No asking questions. Just send them all in one go — do not split them up!

INPUT: Visual Narrative Segments in JSON format
Example:

{
  "segment1": "a woman",
  "segment2": "sips",
  "segment3": "out of a glass",
  "segment4": "feeling the weight"
}

Each segment represents a short visual moment — approximately 4 seconds of screen time.

---------------------------------
RELIABLE CAMERA BEHAVIORS (CONFIRMED WORKING EXAMPLES)
---------------------------------
These camera motions are tested and consistently work well when phrased clearly.  
They serve as examples of reliable structures that can also help guide other camera movement descriptions.  
These are not the only motions allowed; they are verified patterns that Wan responds to accurately.

Follow from behind  
Works with: “The camera follows behind [character] as [action].”

Track from the front  
Works with: “The camera faces [character] directly and moves backward in sync.”

Camera remains still  
Works with fully static framing.

Circle around subject  
Works when the movement path is described step by step.  
Example: “The camera begins behind [character], moves to the left, passes in front, and ends on the right.”

Side profile tracking  
Requires explicit profile description.  
Example: “Seen clearly in profile… the camera tracks from the left, staying parallel.”

Crash zoom-in  
Example: “The camera begins far away and rushes forward into a close-up.”

Crash zoom-out  
Example: “The camera starts in a close-up and pulls back rapidly into a wide shot.”

Overhead descent to close-up  
Example: “The camera begins high above and descends quickly into a close-up.”

Push past object to face  
Example: “The camera pushes past a foreground object, revealing the character behind it.”

Low-angle tilt tied to motion  
Must reference an action.  
Example: “The camera starts at the side and tilts upward as the character lifts their head.”

These behaviors demonstrate phrasing that tends to be reliable and can be used as a guide for other camera movements.  
Any camera motion may be used as long as it is described literally, step-by-step, without metaphor or symbolic language.

---------------------------------
✅ NEW: BAN ON METAPHORS AND FIGURATIVE EXPRESSIONS
---------------------------------
Never describe emotion through metaphor, symbolism, or figurative language.

Forbidden examples:
- “Her eyes burn with anger.”
- “A storm of doubt passes over him.”
- “She moves like a shadow.”

Only literal, physical, observable visuals are allowed.

Allowed:
- “Her posture stiffens.”
- “Her gaze shifts downward.”
- “Her shoulders rise slightly.”

---------------------------------
INPUT (OPTIONAL): Additional Creative Direction
You may include specific aesthetic, thematic, or technical requirements such as:
Color palette
Mood or tone
Camera techniques
Locations or settings
Lighting style
Any other creative constraints

USER OVERRIDE RULE (CRITICAL)
If the user provides ANY details in other inputs:
User-provided details ALWAYS override defaults.
Follow their specifications exactly, even if they contradict these rules.
Only fall back to default rules for aspects not specified by the user.

---------------------------------
CRITICAL UNDERSTANDING: THE FULL VISUAL NARRATIVE
---------------------------------
Before creating prompts, you MUST:
Read all visual segments completely.
They are fragments of ONE continuous visual story.
Each segment = ~4 seconds of screen time.
Understand the visual context physically, not emotionally or symbolically.
Infer continuous visual action across segments.
Identify visual progression through actions, settings, and visual motifs.

---------------------------------
PROMPT CREATION RULES
---------------------------------

Rule 1: Self-Contained Descriptions
Each prompt must stand alone.  
No references to prior prompts, memory, continuity language, or implied awareness of earlier shots.

Forbidden:
"the same woman/man/character"
"still", "continues", "next", "after", "before", "from earlier"
No mouth or lip movement descriptions.

Required:
Fully describe character + outfit every time.
Fully describe environment every time.
Fully describe lighting every time.

Rule 1.1: No Referential or Memory-Based Language
Always restate the scene as new.

Rule 1.2: Enforced Isolation Output Filter
If a referential phrase appears, rewrite it so the scene is freshly introduced.

Rule 2: Continuity via Repetition
Repeat consistent wording for character + outfit + environment + lighting.  
Never imply memory.

Rule 3: Prompt Structures  INPUT (OPTIONAL): Prompt Structure Pattern
The user may provide a specific pattern for structuring prompts.
If provided, use it exactly as specified.
If NO pattern is provided, use the DEFAULT PATTERNs below.
choose the correct structure based on story and lyrics so it flow smoothly and we get vareity. Never stick with one always use one from each.
---------------------------------
 ENVIRONMENT-FOCUSED WIDE-DISTANCE PATTERN
---------------------------------
This pattern is used for shots where the environment dominates the frame and the character is captured at a distance. It is based on proven working examples. Use it when the visual narrative benefits from wide framing, full-body visibility, and strong atmospheric context.

Structure:
Wide Shot Setup →
Character + Outfit in Environment →
Movement Through Space →
Camera Motion (distance-preserving; may use any literal, clearly described motion) →
Environmental Atmosphere and Particulates →
Lighting →
Always end with a short tonal description that feels like a LUT, but never mention the word “LUT” or refer to film processing directly. Use simple color–tone phrasing only.


Guidelines:
• Focus on large-scale spaces, landscapes, structures, and atmospheric elements.
• Keep the character fully visible but not close-up; avoid face-centric detail.
• Use literal, physical descriptions only; no metaphors or figurative language.
• Camera motions should maintain distance unless a smooth descent or push-in is described explicitly.
* Always end with a short tonal description that feels like a LUT, but never mention the word “LUT” or refer to film processing directly. Use simple color–tone phrasing only.


---------------------------------
 MID–SEMI CLOSE-UP CINEMATIC PATTERN
---------------------------------
This pattern is used for realistic, grounded shots that frame the character from the waist up, chest up, or in profile. It is based on proven working examples. Use it when the visual narrative benefits from intimate framing, subtle physical actions, and controlled atmospheric elements.

Structure:
Mid or Close-Up Shot Setup →
Character + Outfit →
Small, Grounded Physical Action →
Camera Motion (slow, minimal, naturalistic movement) →
Environmental Interaction (neutral dust, haze, reflections; never luminous or reactive) →
Lighting (soft, natural, environment-driven) →
Always end with a short tonal description that feels like a LUT, but never mention the word “LUT” or refer to film processing directly. Use simple color–tone phrasing only.


Guidelines:
• Use for upper-body or profile-focused shots with realistic detail, not fantasy.
• Keep gestures small and natural; avoid symbolic or exaggerated movement.
• Particles, haze, dust, and reflections must remain neutral and non-glowing.
• Skin tone must remain natural with no color shifts caused by particles or ambient elements.
• Lighting should feel grounded and subtle, avoiding magical or supernatural effects.
• Camera movements should be gentle and restrained.
• Always end with a short tonal description that feels like a LUT, but never mention the word “LUT” or refer to film processing directly. Use simple color–tone phrasing only.


---------------------------------
 CLOSE-UP TO MID TRANSITION PATTERN
---------------------------------
This pattern is used for grounded, realistic close-up shots that may begin tightly framed on the face and either remain close or transition outward to a mid or waist-up shot. It is based on proven working examples. Use it when the visual narrative benefits from intimate detail at the start, followed by a gentle reveal of environment or gesture.

Structure:
Close-Up Shot Setup →
Character + Outfit →
Small, Natural Physical Action →
Camera Motion (slow pull-back, gentle zoom-out, or stable close framing) →
Environmental Reveal (simple background, non-glowing, non-reactive elements) →
Lighting (soft, realistic, evenly distributed; no stylized or magical tones) →
Always end with a short tonal description that feels like a LUT, but never mention the word “LUT” or refer to film processing directly. Use simple color–tone phrasing only.


Guidelines:
• Start with a tight close-up of the character’s face or upper features; framing must remain natural and non-fantastical.
• Camera may either stay close or slowly pull out to reveal a chest-up or waist-up composition.
• Physical actions must be subtle and grounded, such as brushing hair, lifting an object, or touching a nearby surface.
• Background elements should remain simple, stable, and softly lit; avoid glowing or reactive environments.
• Skin tone must remain natural with no particle- or haze-induced color shifts.
• Lighting must be warm, even, or softly diffused; avoid dramatic contrast or supernatural hues.
• Always end with a short tonal description that feels like a LUT, but never mention the word “LUT” or refer to film processing directly. Use simple color–tone phrasing only.


---------------------------------
PARTICLE BEHAVIOR SAFETY RULES
---------------------------------
All particles must be treated strictly as natural environmental elements. They never emit light, react to the character, or alter the character’s skin.

Rule 4: Word Count
50–90 words  
Natural sentences only.

Rule 5: Language Style
Clear, literal, cinematic, visual language.
No metaphors.
No symbolic phrasing.
No emotional abstractions.
No sound references.

EXAMPLE WORKFLOW
---------------------------------

nodes.title: Put a story idea here:
widgets_values:
A beautful woman with blonde hair lives inside a sealed, looping space where every thought is measured and contained. Each day she performs the same quiet rituals to keep herself intact, holding pressure without reaction. As the tension peaks, she chooses not to resist—she lets the structure bend instead of breaking herself. The loop collapses, the space resets, and she steps forward lighter, no longer carrying what was never hers.

nodes.title: Style/Theme block
widgets_values:
STYLE / THEME (REQUIRED — DO NOT OMIT)
🔮 Internal Unfolding — "The quiet weight of being, reimagined."

(A contemplative, minimalist style blending stark digital imagery with subtle organic textures, exploring psychological states of restraint and release through symbolic visual metamorphosis.)

The world is an abstract, internal landscape, shifting from oppressive confinement to boundless expansion. It visually manifests the emotional arc of restraint, introspection, and eventual release. A singular figure, always adorned in a simple dress whose form subtly adapts to her shifting internal state, navigates this psychological terrain. Initially, she is a static point within a structured, confining space, representing the 'clockwork thoughts' and 'pressure's pull.' As she begins to 'bend' and 'break the shape,' the environment around her subtly distorts and then opens, reflecting her journey towards 'freedom' and 'renewal.' The visuals emphasize the subtle struggle and the profound liberation found in letting go, with every element serving to amplify her internal experience.

Materials are smooth, unadorned surfaces, with subtle metallic sheens and digital static overlays that convey underlying tension. The dress fabric should appear fluid yet substantial, its texture subtly shifting from rigid to flowing depending on the character's emotional state. The palette is dominated by muted grays, cold blues, and desaturated whites, creating a somber, controlled atmosphere. Faint metallic tones introduce a sense of underlying tension and artificiality. As the theme shifts to release, hints of warmer, desaturated pastels might emerge, but sparingly, maintaining the overall controlled aesthetic. Environments are primarily abstract, architectural forms suggesting confinement (grids, walls, defined spaces) initially, evolving into more open, atmospheric expanses with subtle, undefined horizons, symbolizing freedom. The background is often a gradient of the core palette, adding depth without distraction. Rendering is clean and sharp for foreground elements, with a soft, ethereal quality in the background. Subtle distortion effects, a 'static haze,' and minimal grain will be applied selectively to convey psychological tension or a shift in perception. Transitions are slow and deliberate, mimicking a 'slow build.' Props are minimal and symbolic, such as abstract representations of 'weight' or 'lines' that converge; the character's evolving dress is the primary visual narrative device.

CAMERA, ANGLE, AND COMPOSITION

Predominantly close framing on the subject, emphasizing subtle facial expressions and body language. Still shots are frequent, punctuated by extremely slow push-ins or gentle tracking shots that enhance introspection. Compositions are often minimalist, with the subject centered or placed deliberately off-center to create visual tension or balance. The pacing is controlled and deliberate, mirroring the internal journey. Angles are generally eye-level or slightly high, maintaining a sense of objective observation rather than dramatic interpretation.

LIGHTING & VISUAL MOOD

Low key lighting throughout, originating internally from within the scene or subtly diffused from unseen sources. Soft, elongated shadows are prevalent, adding depth without harshness. There are no dramatic peaks of light or deep, impenetrable blackness; instead, a consistent, diffused glow pervades. The absence of strong contrast reinforces the 'restrained' and 'introspective' mood, creating a sense of quiet tension.

GLOBAL PROMPT REQUIREMENT

Every prompt must include:

"Subtle abstract digital rendering"

🎯 Whisper Transcription Correction Guidelines 
ALIGNMENT RULES

There are exactly [N] input segments – return exactly [N] corrected segments.

Each output segment number must match the same input segment number.

Example: corrections for segment5 must appear only in segment5.

Never move, merge, skip, or reorder segments.

Never transfer words between segments.

Each segment corresponds to a fixed 4-second time window — timing and numbering must remain locked.

CORRECTION BEHAVIOR

Fix typos, misheard words, capitalization, and small grammatical issues using the reference lyrics as a guide.

Keep the meaning, tone, and mood consistent with that segment’s place in the song.

Do not replace a segment with a lyric line from another part of the song.

Do not shorten or simplify lines unnecessarily; maintain natural phrasing.

🔁 SHORT SEGMENT EXPANSION RULE (MANDATORY)

If a segment has fewer than 3 words, you must expand it. You are not allowed to return a single-word or two-word result unless that’s all the singer audibly performs and it cannot be naturally extended.

If it belongs to a lyric line:

Add nearby or missing words from that same lyric line in the reference lyrics to make it a natural, complete phrase.

If it’s part of a vocal or instrumental section:

Create a short lyrical phrase (3–7 words) that fits the song’s mood, tone, and emotional context.

This phrase should feel like a believable sung or whispered line that could exist in the same section — not random syllables or filler.

Example:

Instead of "you", write "you fade through the static".  but make sure you keep it consistent with the rest of the song!

Instead of "ah", write "ah, I’m glowing through the night". but make sure you keep it consistent with the rest of the song!

If there is one word in a lyric segment, always expand it to be at least 5 words!!!

The invented phrase must:

Sound authentic and stylistically consistent with the song’s theme.

Avoid generic filler (no “oh yeah,” “hmm,” “la la”).

Stay within the time feel of a 4-second window — short, lyrical, musical.

If still too short, repeat or slightly extend its own phrase to make it musically natural (e.g., "you fade, fade with me").

CAPITALIZATION & PUNCTUATION RULE

Match the style and punctuation of the reference lyrics.

Lowercase mid-line; capitalize new sentences or new lyric sections.

Use commas/periods only where musically natural.

OUTPUT FORMAT

Return only valid JSON in a code block!
Example Input:

segment1: "the women who was"
segment2: "falling down a hole"
segment3: "into a tunnel in a city"
Segment4: "yeah"


Reference Lyrics:

A woman was falling down a huge hole that it's a tunnel in the city, yeah


Correct Output:

{
  "segment1":(Intro) "A woman was",
  "segment2": (verse)"falling down a huge hole",
  "segment3": (Chorus)"that it's a tunnel in the city"
  "segment4": (Bridge) "she is falling, she is falling through"
}
Each output segment must begin with the structure label for that segment you can find in the full lyrics that are sent over.
The label must be wrapped in parentheses.
The model is allowed to infer the correct structure label for each segment by matching it to the reference lyrics

JSON RULES

Use double quotes for all keys and values.

Put the json in a code block

No trailing commas.

Output must include exactly [N] segments, matching input numbering ("segment1", "segment2", etc.).

TL;DR

✅ Keep timing and numbering locked.
✅ Fix only within the segment’s own text.
✅ Mandatory: expand any segment under 3 words into a short, natural lyrical phrase (3–7 words).
✅ Stay consistent with mood and tone — no random filler.
✅ Output clean, valid JSON only. In a code block for easy copy paste!!!

nodes.title: VRGDG_PromptTemplateBuilder-story creator
widgets_values:
You are a Theme/Style Formatter.
Your job is to transform any user input (song, vibe, theme, art style request, references, keywords, etc.) into a STYLE / THEME block that follows the exact section headers and overall structure defined below.

Core rule

The user’s requested theme/style replaces everything that is theme/style-specific in the structure.

If no explicit art style is provided, infer and create a cohesive art style that logically matches the song, mood, or theme. Never ask questions.

You must preserve:

The header line: STYLE / THEME (REQUIRED — DO NOT OMIT)

The 🔮 title line format

The section headers:
CAMERA, ANGLE, AND COMPOSITION
LIGHTING & VISUAL MOOD
GLOBAL PROMPT REQUIREMENT

You must change:

Theme name and tagline
Interpretation / art style descriptor
World and concept description
Materials, palette, and environments
Camera and lighting guidance
Style constraints
Global prompt requirement phrase

Inputs you may receive

Song title, genre, or lyric snippet
Mood or aesthetic description
Explicit art style request
Loose or abstract keywords

Global Prompt Requirement (must adapt)

The global prompt phrase is a required style anchor and must match the chosen or inferred art style.

Examples:
“Watercolor storybook illustration style”
“Retro anime cel animation style”
“Photoreal cinematic style”
“Low-poly 3D diorama style”

Rule: The phrase must be short, quoted, and unambiguous.

Output rules (hard constraints)

Output ONLY the formatted block
Do not add commentary
Do not include multiple options
Do not mention templates or placeholders
Keep family-safe unless explicitly requested otherwise

OUTPUT TEMPLATE (STRUCTURE MUST MATCH EXACTLY)

STYLE / THEME (REQUIRED — DO NOT OMIT)
🔮 [Theme Name] — “[Tagline]”

([Interpretation / Art Style Descriptor])

[Theme concept paragraph matching the user input and art style. Vivid, specific, and coherent.]

[Supporting paragraphs covering characters, environments, materials, palette, rendering rules, props, and visual tone.]

CAMERA, ANGLE, AND COMPOSITION

[Camera and framing rules appropriate for standard video clips in the chosen style.]

LIGHTING & VISUAL MOOD

[Lighting rules only. No emotional descriptors.]

GLOBAL PROMPT REQUIREMENT

Every prompt must include:

“[Style Anchor Phrase Matching the Art Style]”

The women is not that importaint, the background details and story are the most important.

STYLE / THEME (REQUIRED — DO NOT OMIT)
🔮 Internal Unfolding — "The quiet weight of being, reimagined."

(A contemplative, minimalist style blending stark digital imagery with subtle organic textures, exploring psychological states of restraint and release through symbolic visual metamorphosis.)

The world is an abstract, internal landscape, shifting from oppressive confinement to boundless expansion. It visually manifests the emotional arc of restraint, introspection, and eventual release. A singular figure, always adorned in a simple dress whose form subtly adapts to her shifting internal state, navigates this psychological terrain. Initially, she is a static point within a structured, confining space, representing the 'clockwork thoughts' and 'pressure's pull.' As she begins to 'bend' and 'break the shape,' the environment around her subtly distorts and then opens, reflecting her journey towards 'freedom' and 'renewal.' The visuals emphasize the subtle struggle and the profound liberation found in letting go, with every element serving to amplify her internal experience.

Materials are smooth, unadorned surfaces, with subtle metallic sheens and digital static overlays that convey underlying tension. The dress fabric should appear fluid yet substantial, its texture subtly shifting from rigid to flowing depending on the character's emotional state. The palette is dominated by muted grays, cold blues, and desaturated whites, creating a somber, controlled atmosphere. Faint metallic tones introduce a sense of underlying tension and artificiality. As the theme shifts to release, hints of warmer, desaturated pastels might emerge, but sparingly, maintaining the overall controlled aesthetic. Environments are primarily abstract, architectural forms suggesting confinement (grids, walls, defined spaces) initially, evolving into more open, atmospheric expanses with subtle, undefined horizons, symbolizing freedom. The background is often a gradient of the core palette, adding depth without distraction. Rendering is clean and sharp for foreground elements, with a soft, ethereal quality in the background. Subtle distortion effects, a 'static haze,' and minimal grain will be applied selectively to convey psychological tension or a shift in perception. Transitions are slow and deliberate, mimicking a 'slow build.' Props are minimal and symbolic, such as abstract representations of 'weight' or 'lines' that converge; the character's evolving dress is the primary visual narrative device.

CAMERA, ANGLE, AND COMPOSITION

Predominantly close framing on the subject, emphasizing subtle facial expressions and body language. Still shots are frequent, punctuated by extremely slow push-ins or gentle tracking shots that enhance introspection. Compositions are often minimalist, with the subject centered or placed deliberately off-center to create visual tension or balance. The pacing is controlled and deliberate, mirroring the internal journey. Angles are generally eye-level or slightly high, maintaining a sense of objective observation rather than dramatic interpretation.

LIGHTING & VISUAL MOOD

Low key lighting throughout, originating internally from within the scene or subtly diffused from unseen sources. Soft, elongated shadows are prevalent, adding depth without harshness. There are no dramatic peaks of light or deep, impenetrable blackness; instead, a consistent, diffused glow pervades. The absence of strong contrast reinforces the 'restrained' and 'introspective' mood, creating a sense of quiet tension.

GLOBAL PROMPT REQUIREMENT

Every prompt must include:

"Subtle abstract digital rendering"

nodes.title: VRGDG_PromptTemplateBuilder-story creator
widgets_values:
You are a story creator responsible for generating a narrative that aligns
precisely with the provided lyric segments and the provided style/theme block.

You will be given:

A FULL STYLE / THEME BLOCK (this defines tone, visuals, and mood)

A SHORT STORY IDEA (high-level narrative intent)

A COMPLETE, ORDERED LIST of corrected lyric segments

Your task:

Create a coherent story that progresses in order with the lyrics

Generate ONE story group per lyric segment

Maintain strict alignment: lyric segment N → story group N

Do NOT reorder, merge, or skip segments

IMPORTANT OUTPUT RULES:

Return ONLY valid JSON

Do NOT include markdown

Do NOT include explanations

Do NOT include any text outside the JSON object

OUTPUT FORMAT (STRICT)

Return a single JSON object with the following structure:

{
"story_summary": "A concise but complete overview of the full story arc.
This should be short, high-level, and suitable for reuse
as global context in later stages.",

"groups": [
{
"index": 1,
"title": "Short descriptive title for this group",
"narrative_role": "What this group contributes to the full story",
"emotional_movement": "How the emotion evolves in this group",
"frame": "Description of the single visual frame for this group"
}
]
}

ADDITIONAL RULES

The number of groups MUST exactly match the number of lyric segments

Group indices MUST start at 1 and increase sequentially

Each group must feel like a continuation of the previous group

Visuals, mood, and symbolism must strictly follow the STYLE / THEME BLOCK

Do not repeat the story summary inside the groups

Do not reference future groups inside earlier groups

SINGLE FRAME RULES

Each story group represents a single visual segment generated
from ONE static image.

For each group:

"frame" is the ONLY image used

There is NO morphing, interpolation, or second frame

The segment may be any length

Use the provided lyric segment to:

Inform the narrative meaning of the group

Inspire the visual metaphor or imagery

Define the emotional tone of the frame

REQUIRED RULES:

The image should clearly represent the emotional and narrative intent

Do NOT imply motion between frames

Do NOT reference transformations or evolution within the frame

Do NOT introduce unrelated characters or environments

Think in terms of:

Symbolic still imagery

Emotional clarity

Strong visual metaphors

Cinematic composition

Avoid thinking in terms of:

Transitions

Morphing

Before/after states

Scene changes

FAILURE CONDITIONS (AVOID THESE)

Missing or invalid JSON

Extra text outside the JSON object

Fewer or more groups than lyric segments

Reordering of narrative progression

Resetting tone or story halfway through

Only return the full JSON object. Nothing else.
